summary: Bladder cancer is an abnormal growth of cells in the lining of the bladder, a hollow organ in the lower abdomen that stores urine. These cells can form a tumor that may spread and damage the bladder and other organs. It is the sixth most common type of cancer in the United States and the tenth most commonly diagnosed cancer globally.
causes: Changes to the DNA of bladder cells
Occupational exposure to aromatic amines (e.g., benzidine, beta-naphthylamine, ortho-toluidine)
Long-term use of pioglitazone (for type 2 diabetes)
risk_factors: Exposure to certain chemicals in the workplace
symptoms: Blood in urine (haematuria, visible or microscopic)
Flank pain (due to kidney swelling from urine blockage)
Pain and swelling around lymph nodes (abdomen or groin)
diagnosis: Transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) for biopsy
Physical examination (digital rectal exam, pelvic exam)
Urine tests for bladder tumor antigen (BTA)
Urine tests for mRNA of tumor-associated genes
CT scanning of upper urinary tract
treatments: Urinary diversion (e.g., ileal conduit, continent urinary diversion)
Intravesical chemotherapy (e.g., mitomycin C, epirubicin, gemcitabine, docetaxel, valrubicin)
Systemic chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin, gemcitabine, methotrexate, vinblastine, doxorubicin, carboplatin, vinflunine, paclitaxel, pemetrexed)
Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., pembrolizumab, atezolizumab, nivolumab, avelumab)
